questions.correct_answer: B. It tends to occur in the spine and the flat bones
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It tends to occur in the spine and the flat bones Osteoblastomas are rare and benign primary bone tumors. They may be locally aggressive and affect the axial skeleton more often than their histologic relative, osteoid osteoma.

Highyeild:

OSTEOBLASTOMA 17:50 Rare bone-forming tumors. MC presentation - Pain→ Painful Scoliosis / Neurological deficit (some cases) Post. Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Osteoblastoma Occurs At 20-40 Years Of Age Option: C . With spinal lesions, painful scoliosis is a common presenting symptom. The area will be swollen and tender, with a decreased range of motion. Option: D. Pathology Osteoblastoma is histologically similar to an osteoid osteoma except that it is much larger. The tumor is bone and osteoid forming and is comprised of osteoblasts. There is high associated vascularity.

questions.text: While examining a patient with a suspected bone tumor, the swelling is pulsatile. Radiological examination demonstrates Sunburst appearance. It is seen in Which Of The Following Condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Osteosarcoma OSTEOSARCOMA 00:10 Osteoid production by malignant cells. MC nonhematological malignancy of bones. 2 types: 1° 05 → seen in young age group 2nd decade 2°05 → Post Radiation / Paget's / OM, etc.

Highyeild:

Osteosarcoma is an aggressive malignant neoplasm arising from primitive transformed cells of mesenchymal origin (and thus a sarcoma) that exhibit osteoblastic differentiation and produce malignant osteoid. Sun Ray's Appearance is primary bone cancer's most common radiological finding. If the lesion grows rapidly but steadily, the periosteum will not have enough time to lay down a thin shell of bone. In such cases, the tiny fibers that connect the periosteum to the bone ( Sharpey’s fibers ) become stretched out perpendicular to the bone. When these fibers ossify, they produce a pattern sometimes called a "sunburst" periosteal reaction.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Unicameral bone cyst The age, history, examination, and radiographic findings point to the diagnosis of the unicameral bone cyst. Unicameral Bone Cyst is a benign bone lesion found in the metaphysis of long bones in childhood and adolescence. Male: Female ratio is 3:1.
